Joint contractures from multiple causes (trauma, burns, immobility, neurologic). Incidence ~40-60 per 100k per year. Lower confidence due to heterogeneity.
Febrile seizures affect 2-5% of children (400 per 100k total population per year). Age-limited condition, typically 6 months to 5 years.
source: Steering Committee on Quality Improvement and Management (2008). Febrile seizures guideline. Pediatrics. 121(6):1281-1286

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major corneal conditions: infectious keratitis (~20 per 100k), corneal abrasions/trauma (~15 per 100k), corneal ulcers (~10 per 100k), corneal dystrophies (~5 per 100k). Total ~50 per 100k. Heterogeneous mix of infectious, traumatic, and degenerative conditions. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and limited comprehensive epidemiological data.

Coronary arteriosclerosis is a chronic progressive condition; prevalence is the appropriate metric. Global prevalence estimated at ~5.5% (5,500 per 100k) based on WHO GBD 2005 cardiovascular disease data. High variation by region - higher in developed nations (6-8%), lower in developing regions (3-4%).
source: Murray CJ et al. (2006). The Global Burden of Disease 2005: Methods and results. Lancet. 368(9551):1969-1996

reasoning: Ischemic heart disease. Global incidence ~130-150 per 100k per year (140 estimate) based on WHO 2005 data. Leading cause of death globally.
source: WHO Global Burden of Disease 2005

reasoning: Reporting incidence (new diagnoses). Global average ~3 per 100k person-years based on systematic reviews, though rates vary dramatically (0.5-20 per 100k) with highest in North America and Europe.
source: Loftus EV Jr. (2004). Clinical epidemiology of inflammatory bowel disease: Incidence, prevalence, and environmental influences. Gastroenterology. 126(6):1504-1517

reasoning: Abnormal immunoglobulin precipitation. Incidence ~1-2 per 100k per year. Associated with hepatitis C and autoimmune diseases. Lower confidence due to underdiagnosis.

Reporting incidence. Rare salivary gland malignancy, ~0.3-0.5 per 100k based on SEER and European cancer registry data. Can occur in various sites (salivary, breast, respiratory tract). Moderate confidence due to rarity and variable anatomic presentation.
source: Coca-Pelaz A et al. (2015). Salivary gland cancer: epidemiology. Oral Oncol. 51(12):1095-1103

reasoning: Benign cystic tumor occurring in multiple organs (ovary most common, also pancreas, kidney). Estimated ~15 per 100k based primarily on ovarian cystadenomas. Confidence reduced due to lack of organ specificity and limited population-based incidence data.

Reporting birth incidence of cystic fibrosis. Global incidence approximately 1.5 per 100k live births (varies by ethnicity: 3-4 per 100k in Caucasians, <1 per 100k in Asian populations). Based on newborn screening data and patient registries.
source: Farrell PM et al. (2008). The prevalence of cystic fibrosis in the European Union. J Cyst Fibros. 7(5):450-453

reasoning: Umbrella term too broad. Cysts occur in all organs (kidney, ovary, liver, breast, etc.) with vastly different prevalence. Requires organ specification.

Reporting incidence of diagnosed CMV infections at ~50 per 100k person-years. Includes symptomatic primary infections, congenital CMV, and reactivation disease. Wide variation in surveillance definitions limits confidence.
source: Cannon MJ et al. (2010). Review of cytomegalovirus seroprevalence and demographic characteristics associated with infection. Rev Med Virol. 20(4):202-213

reasoning: Dysphagia (swallowing disorders) incidence estimated at ~18 per 100k in general adult population based on community studies. Higher in elderly and post-stroke populations.
source: Bhattacharyya N. (2014). The prevalence of dysphagia among adults in the United States. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 151:765-769

reasoning: Delirium incidence ~200 per 100k in hospitalized elderly. Prevalence highly variable by setting.
source: Siddiqi N et al. (2016). Delirium. Lancet. 388(10047):911-922

reasoning: Early-onset dementia (before age 65). Represents approximately 5-10% of all dementia cases. Estimated at ~9 per 100k person-years based on epidemiological studies. Lower confidence due to less robust population-based data compared to late-onset dementia.
source: Harvey RJ et al. (2003). Epidemiology of presenile dementia. Neurology. 60(9):1443-1447

reasoning: Epidemiological data for Dental Enamel Hypoplasia requires further investigation.
Rare genetic disorder affecting dentin formation. Estimated ~1 per 100,000 based on case reports.
Autosomal dominant dentin disorder. Estimated ~1 per 6,000-8,000 births (~1-1.5 per 100k).
source: Dental genetic registries

reasoning: Synonym for depressive disorder. Depression measured as prevalence (existing cases). WHO 2005 data estimates ~3.2% global prevalence (3,200 per 100k).
source: WHO World Health Report 2005

reasoning: Historical term for late-life depression, now classified under Major Depressive Disorder. Estimated ~180 per 100k based on MDD incidence in middle-aged/elderly adults. Moderate-low confidence due to outdated terminology and extrapolation from general MDD data.
source: Waraich P et al. (2004). Prevalence and incidence studies of mood disorders: a systematic review of the literature. Can J Psychiatry. 49(2):124-138

reasoning: Depression measured as prevalence (existing cases) rather than incidence. WHO 2005 data estimates ~3.2% global prevalence (3,200 per 100k) for depressive disorders.
source: WHO World Health Report 2005

reasoning: Dermatitis (contact, seborrheic) affects ~2000 per 100k. Annual incidence estimated ~200 per 100k.
source: Stern RS et al. (1984). Diagnostic criteria for dermatitis. J Am Acad Dermatol. 10(1):44-56

reasoning: Atopic dermatitis incidence ~120 per 100k, prevalence ~1500 per 100k in developed countries.
source: Flohr C et al. (2010). The epidemiology of atopic dermatitis. Clin Exp Allergy. 40(2):178-188

reasoning: Systemic sclerosis. Incidence ~1.5-2.3 per 100k per year (1.9 estimate) based on registry studies.
source: Mayes MD et al. (2003). Prevalence, incidence of systemic sclerosis. Arthritis Rheum. 48(8):2246-2255

reasoning: Reporting incidence of new diabetes diagnoses. Broad umbrella including Type 1 (~10% of cases), Type 2 (~90%), gestational, and other forms. Global incidence ~17 per 100k person-years from IDF 2005 data, predominantly Type 2.
source: IDF Diabetes Atlas 2005

reasoning: Reporting incidence (new diagnoses) of diabetes mellitus, primarily Type 1 and Type 2. Global incidence from IDF 2005 data: ~16.5 per 100k person-years. Predominantly Type 2 diabetes in adults.
source: IDF Diabetes Atlas 2005

reasoning: Experimental diabetes mellitus is not a clinical disease entity found in human populations. This CUI refers to induced or experimental diabetes in research models (animal studies, in vitro systems). Cannot be mapped to epidemiological incidence data.
Type 1 diabetes (insulin-dependent) incidence from IDF 2005 data: ~10.5 per 100k globally, with significant geographic variation (higher in Nordic countries, lower in Asia).
source: IDF Diabetes Atlas 2005, DIAMOND Project data

reasoning: Reporting incidence (new diagnoses). Type 2 diabetes global incidence from IDF 2005 data: approximately 16.5 per 100k person-years, accounting for ~90% of all diabetes cases.
source: IDF Diabetes Atlas 2005

reasoning: Diabetic micro and macrovascular complications develop in 30-40% of diabetic patients annually. With global diabetes prevalence ~400 per 100k and annual complication incidence ~45%, estimated ~180 per 100k globally. Includes diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy complications.
source: American Diabetes Association Standards of Medical Care. Diabetes Care. 2005;28 Suppl 1:S4-S36

reasoning: Diabetic nephropathy develops in approximately 20-40% of diabetic patients over their lifetime. With global diabetes prevalence ~6% in 2005 and estimated 2-3% annual incidence among diabetics, overall population incidence ~8.5 per 100k person-years.
source: Molitch ME et al. (2004). Nephropathy in diabetes. Diabetes Care. 27(suppl 1):S79-S83

reasoning: Diastematomyelia (spinal cord split) estimated at 2 per 100,000 live births.

Diphtheria is a rare infectious disease with highly variable incidence based on vaccination coverage. Global weighted average estimated at ~0.3 per 100k person-years, with incidence <0.01 in well-vaccinated regions and 1-10+ per 100k in areas with low vaccination coverage. WHO surveillance data shows declining trends in vaccinated populations.
source: WHO Global Health Observatory diphtheria surveillance data and World Immunization Survey (2005)

reasoning: Down syndrome (trisomy 21) has well-established birth incidence of ~1 per 600-700 live births globally (~143 per 100k live births). Reporting both incidence at birth and population prevalence (~250 per 100k) accounting for improved survival rates and demographic distribution. Strong epidemiological data from multiple birth defect registries.
source: CDC National Birth Defects Prevention Network (2005) and WHO Global Health Observatory, based on surveillance data from 37 countries

reasoning: Drug dependence/substance use disorders measured as prevalence. WHO 2004 data estimated ~5.5% global prevalence of drug use disorders (5,500 per 100k). Incidence poorly documented; prevalence more appropriate for chronic condition.
source: WHO (2004). Neuroscience of psychoactive substance use and dependence. World Health Organization

reasoning: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) incidence ~1 in 3,500-5,000 male births (~2.5 per 100k live births). X-linked recessive disorder with robust epidemiological data from multiple registries.
source: Mah JK et al. (2014). A systematic review and meta-analysis on the epidemiology of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy. Neuromuscul Disord. 24(6):482-491

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major causes of proportionate and disproportionate short stature: achondroplasia (~4), growth hormone deficiency (~5), Turner syndrome (~2.5), skeletal dysplasias (~8), other genetic/metabolic causes (~5) = ~25 per 100k births. Heterogeneous conditions with overlap and diagnostic challenges.

Pituitary dwarfism is the clinical manifestation of severe growth hormone deficiency presenting in childhood. Incidence estimated at ~1 per 12,500 births based on congenital GHD prevalence studies. Related to but distinct from genetic GHD syndromes and non-pituitary causes of dwarfism. Confidence limited by lack of specific epidemiological data for this clinical phenotype.
Shigellosis. Global incidence ~400-600 per 100k per year (500 estimate), higher in developing countries and children.
Drug-induced dyskinesia (tardive dyskinesia from antipsychotics) estimated at ~5% of treated patients annually, roughly 5 per 100k general population. Limited population-based data.
Chronic condition measured as prevalence. Dysplastic nevus syndrome affects 2-5% of population (~3,500 per 100k) based on dermatological surveys.
source: Tucker MA et al. (1997). Clinically recognized dysplastic nevi. JAMA. 277(18):1439-1444

reasoning: Chronic depressive disorder measured as prevalence. Global prevalence ~3-4% (3,600 per 100k) based on WHO mental health surveys circa 2004.
source: Waraich P et al. (2004). Prevalence and incidence studies of mood disorders: a systematic review of the literature. Can J Psychiatry. 49(2):124-38

reasoning: Atopic dermatitis/eczema affects ~2% of population (2000 per 100k). Annual incidence ~150 per 100k.
source: Langan SM et al. (2020). Atopic dermatitis. Lancet. 396(10247):345-360

reasoning: Genetic connective tissue disorder measured as prevalence. Combined EDS prevalence ~1 in 5,000 (20 per 100k) across all subtypes.
source: Malfait F et al. (2017). The Ehlers-Danlos syndromes. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 3:17048

reasoning: Mosquito-borne flavivirus. Incidence ~0.03-0.1 per 100k per year in endemic areas (US). Lower globally. Sporadic outbreaks.
source: CDC ArboNET surveillance

reasoning: Synonym for encephalocele. Birth prevalence ~0.8-1.5 per 100k births, translating to ~0.8 per 100k population per year.
source: Agopian AJ et al. (2013). Descriptive epidemiology of encephalocele. Birth Defects Res A. 97(3):131-139

reasoning: Experimental Autoimmune Encephalomyelitis (EAE) is a research model of multiple sclerosis used in laboratory animals, not a naturally occurring human disease with epidemiological data. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to human incidence rates.
Endometrial cancer incidence ~8 per 100k women globally from GLOBOCAN 2005.
source: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

reasoning: Endometriosis measured as prevalence (~10% of reproductive-age women). Incidence poorly defined due to diagnostic delays and asymptomatic cases.
source: Eskenazi B et al. (1997). Validation study of nonsurgical diagnosis of endometriosis. Fertil Steril. 68(3):518-25

reasoning: Eosinophilia is a laboratory finding (elevated eosinophils), not a specific disease entity. Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major causes: parasitic infections (~500), allergic reactions (~200), drug reactions (~50), eosinophilic syndromes (~100) = ~850 per 100k. Heterogeneous condition with overlap between etiologies.
Ependymoma is a CNS tumor with estimated 1.5 per 100k incidence globally based on cancer registry data.
source: WHO classification of CNS tumors, epidemiological estimates

reasoning: Reporting incidence of new epilepsy diagnoses. Global incidence ~50 per 100k person-years based on WHO estimates for 2005, with higher rates in low-income countries (80-100 per 100k) vs high-income (40-50 per 100k).
source: WHO Atlas: Epilepsy Care in the World (2005)

reasoning: Epidemiological data for Epilepsy, Generalized requires further investigation.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for epilepsies presenting with myoclonic seizures. Includes juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (~5-8 per 100k, ~30% of all epilepsy), progressive myoclonic epilepsies (~2-3 per 100k), and myoclonic seizures in other syndromes (~8-10 per 100k). Aggregate estimate ~18.5 per 100k. Heterogeneous group with significant variability.
Most common focal epilepsy. Incidence ~6-7 per 100k per year (6.5 estimate), representing ~30-40% of all epilepsy.
Seizures originating from uncinate gyrus/mesial temporal structures. Subset of TLE. Incidence ~1 per 100k per year. Lower confidence due to variable definitions.

Umbrella term encompassing benign (polyps, benign tumors ~1-2 per 100k) and malignant esophageal neoplasms (~7 per 100k). Aggregate estimate ~8.5 per 100k combining major subcategories, but confidence reduced due to heterogeneity.
source: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC) with estimate adjustment for benign lesions

reasoning: Fanconi anemia is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder with 15+ known complementation groups (A-N and others). Global birth incidence estimated at ~1 per 200,000 live births, translating to ~5 per 100k person-years. Represents aggregate of multiple genetic subtypes with varying clinical presentations and prognosis.
source: Fanconi Anemia Research Fund (FARF) International Registry and OMIM disease prevalence estimates

reasoning: Fatty liver (hepatic steatosis) measured as prevalence. Global NAFLD prevalence ~25% (25,000 per 100k) circa 2005, driven by obesity epidemic. Incidence not typically reported for this chronic condition.
source: Bedogni G et al. (2005). Prevalence of and risk factors for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease: the Dionysos nutrition and liver study. Hepatology. 42(5):44-52

reasoning: FAS incidence approximately 0.5-2 per 1,000 live births globally, with higher rates in North America and Europe (1-3 per 1,000). Expressed as ~15 per 100k births. Significant geographic variation based on maternal alcohol consumption patterns.
source: May PA et al. (2009). Epidemiology of fetal alcohol syndrome and partial FAS. J Popul Ther Clin Pharmacol. 16(3):e13-e21

reasoning: FGR/IUGR affects ~5-10% of pregnancies globally. With global birth rate ~2000 per 100k population in 2005, estimating ~100 cases per 100k population per year. Moderate confidence; variation in diagnostic criteria.
source: Resnik R (2002). Intrauterine growth restriction. Obstet Gynecol. 99(3):490-496

reasoning: Rare connective tissue malignancy. Incidence ~0.3 per 100k per year (pediatric and adult combined).

Flatfoot is best measured by prevalence, not incidence. Adult prevalence estimates range 20-30% (20,000-30,000 per 100k). Using 25% middle estimate. However, most cases are asymptomatic flexible flatfoot; rigid/symptomatic flatfoot is much less common.
Epidemiological data for Foot Deformities requires further investigation.
Most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. Incidence ~2-3 per 100k births (1 in 4000 males, 1 in 8000 females). Using 2.5 per 100k as average estimate from population screening studies.
source: Hunter J et al. (2014). Epidemiology of fragile X syndrome: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Am J Med Genet A. 164A(7):1648-1658

reasoning: Rare benign neural tumor arising from sympathetic nerve cells. Incidence estimated at 0.15 per 100k based on case reports and tumor registry data. Less common than neuroblastoma; often discovered incidentally. Reporting as incidence (new diagnoses per year) despite rarity. Data quality limited by small number of published epidemiological studies.

Chronic gastritis prevalence varies by geographic region and H. pylori infection rates. Estimated global prevalence at ~12% (12,000 per 100k) based on endoscopic studies. Higher prevalence in developing nations with H. pylori endemicity (15-20%) versus developed nations (5-10%).
source: Malfertheiner P et al. (2005). Current concepts in the management of Helicobacter pylori infection. Gut. 54(7):939-948

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major GI conditions: acute gastroenteritis (~5000), GERD (~3000), IBS (~4000), peptic ulcer disease (~2000), Crohn's disease (~200), ulcerative colitis (~300), celiac disease (~500), diverticulitis (~1500), appendicitis (~1000), colorectal polyps (~5000+). Umbrella term encompasses extremely heterogeneous conditions with vastly different incidence rates and clinical significance.
All GI cancers combined (esophageal, gastric, colorectal, pancreatic, liver). GLOBOCAN 2005 aggregate ~35 per 100k globally.
source: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

reasoning: Lysosomal storage disorder. Birth prevalence ~1 in 40,000-60,000 (0.1 per 100k), higher in Ashkenazi Jews.
source: Grabowski GA (2008). Gaucher disease. Orphanet J Rare Dis. 3:13

reasoning: All glaucoma types combined measured as prevalence. Global prevalence ~3.54% (3,540 per 100k) based on WHO 2005 estimates. Age-related increase.
source: Resnikoff S et al. (2004). Global data on visual impairment. Bull WHO. 82(11):844-851

reasoning: Open-angle glaucoma incidence ~200 per 100k person-years based on population studies. Moderate-high confidence from epidemiological literature, though geographic variation exists.
source: Quigley HA, Broman AT (2006). The number of people with glaucoma worldwide in 2010 and 2020. Br J Ophthalmol. 90(3):262-267

reasoning: Glioblastoma is the most common malignant primary brain tumor. Global incidence ~3-4 per 100k person-years from cancer registry data circa 2005. High confidence due to systematic cancer surveillance.
source: CBTRUS Statistical Report and GLOBOCAN 2005

reasoning: Reporting incidence. Gliomas account for ~80% of malignant brain tumors. Total brain/CNS tumor incidence ~7 per 100k, gliomas ~5.8 per 100k based on CBTRUS and GLOBOCAN 2005 data.
source: CBTRUS Statistical Report: Primary Brain Tumors in the United States, 2000-2004

reasoning: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a histological pattern with multiple etiologies. Primary MPGN (now reclassified as C3GN) and secondary forms (HCV-related, autoimmune) have combined estimated incidence of 1-2 per 100k in developed countries. Geographic variation significant due to HCV prevalence variation. Confidence moderate due to heterogeneous etiology and evolving classification.
source: Nasr SH et al. (2011). Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. J Amer Soc Nephrol. 23(2):214-224

reasoning: All GSD types combined. Birth prevalence ~2-3 per 100k births (2.3 estimate) including types I-VII.
source: Shin YS (2006). Glycogen storage disease. J Inherit Metab Dis. 29(2-3):287-295

reasoning: Pompe disease. Birth prevalence ~0.7-1 per 100k births (0.8 estimate) based on newborn screening programs.
source: Mechtler TP et al. (2012). Neonatal screening for Pompe disease. J Inherit Metab Dis. 35(3):413-420

reasoning: Umbrella term too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses diverse conditions: PCOS (prevalence-based), hypogonadism (chronic), premature ovarian failure, testicular disorders, ovarian tumors, etc. Mix of acute, chronic, congenital conditions with vastly different epidemiology and no coherent aggregate metric.
Gonorrhea: sexually transmitted bacterial infection. Global incidence ~200 per 100k from WHO surveillance data.
source: WHO STI/RTI surveillance

reasoning: Reporting incidence of new gout diagnoses. Population-based studies from UK and US (2000-2005) show incidence ~1.5 per 1000 person-years (150 per 100k), higher in men and increasing with age.
source: Arromdee E et al. (2002). Epidemiology of gout: is the incidence rising? J Rheumatol. 29(11):2403-6

reasoning: Graft-vs-Host Disease (GVHD) is a major complication of allogeneic bone marrow/stem cell transplantation. Occurs in 30-50% of transplant recipients. Global estimate: ~100,000 allogeneic transplants annually with ~40-50% developing GVHD = ~40-50 per 100k general population (but primarily among transplant recipients). Population-based estimate ~45 per 100k.
source: Nassereddine S et al. (2017). Acute graft-vs-host disease: A comprehensive review. Anticancer Res. 37(3):1547-1555

reasoning: Hallucinations are a symptom/sign, not a disease entity. Occurs across multiple conditions (schizophrenia, delirium, Parkinson's, drug effects, sensory deprivation). Cannot meaningfully assign incidence without specifying underlying disease.

Hamartoma is an umbrella term covering benign tumor-like lesions that can occur in virtually any organ system (brain, heart, lung, liver, kidney, GI tract, skin, bone). Without tissue/organ specification, this is too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Incidence rates vary dramatically depending on organ involved and whether lesions are clinically significant or incidental findings.

Multiple hamartoma syndrome (Cowden syndrome / PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome) is a rare autosomal dominant condition caused by PTEN mutations. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k based on case reports. Fewer than 1000 diagnosed cases worldwide. Very limited epidemiological data available.
source: Nelen MR et al. (1999). Germline mutations in the PTEN gene in families with Cowden syndrome. J Med Genet. 36(7):540-543

reasoning: Broad category including oral cavity, pharynx, larynx cancers. GLOBOCAN 2005 shows combined incidence ~10 per 100k globally.
source: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

reasoning: Limited epidemiological data available for Cardiac Arrest.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major cardiovascular events and conditions: myocardial infarction (~150), heart failure incidence (~120), atrial fibrillation (~200), valvular heart disease (~50), congenital heart disease (~8), other cardiac conditions (~322). Total ~850 per 100k. Highly heterogeneous umbrella term with significant overlap between categories.

Reporting incidence of new heart failure cases. Global incidence ~220 per 100k person-years based on Framingham Heart Study and European cohort data from early 2000s. Incidence increases dramatically with age, from <1 per 1000 in young adults to >10 per 1000 in those >65 years.
source: Lloyd-Jones DM et al. (2002). Lifetime risk for developing congestive heart failure: the Framingham Heart Study. Circulation. 106(24):3068-72

reasoning: Reporting incidence of new heart failure diagnoses. Global incidence ~200 per 100k person-years based on epidemiological studies from high-income countries. Framingham and European cohort data circa 2000-2005 show 1-2% annual incidence in older adults.
source: Roger VL et al. (2004). Trends in the incidence and survival of patients with hospitalized myocardial infarction, Olmsted County, Minnesota. JAMA. 292(3):344-50

reasoning: Hematochezia (bright red rectal bleeding) is common symptom of multiple conditions. Estimated incidence ~400 per 100k as presenting symptom.

Umbrella term covering all blood disorders including anemias, leukemias, lymphomas, clotting disorders, and other hematological conditions. Too broad and heterogeneous to provide meaningful aggregate estimate.
Blood in urine from multiple causes (UTI, stones, cancer, glomerular disease). Incidence ~150-250 per 100k per year. Lower confidence due to heterogeneity and transient nature.
Hereditary iron overload. Genetic prevalence (HFE C282Y homozygotes) ~1 in 200-400 in European populations (12.5 per 100k clinical disease).
source: Adams PC et al. (2005). Hemochromatosis. N Engl J Med. 352:1769-1778

reasoning: Hemoglobin F disease likely refers to hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) or related hemoglobinopathies. Genetic condition measured by prevalence, not incidence. Estimated ~100 per 100k globally, but varies widely by ethnicity (higher in African and Mediterranean populations). Limited global systematic data.
HUS, primarily in children. Incidence ~0.5-1.0 per 100k per year (0.7 estimate), often post-E. coli infection.
Umbrella term too broad. Encompasses viral (A, B, C, D, E), autoimmune, alcoholic, drug-induced hepatitis with vastly different incidence rates.
Acute viral hepatitis. Global incidence ~100-200 per 100k per year (150 estimate), higher in developing countries.
source: WHO (2010). Hepatitis A fact sheet.

reasoning: Chronic hepatitis is an umbrella term covering chronic hepatitis B, C, autoimmune hepatitis, and other etiologies. Estimated aggregate incidence ~50 per 100k based on WHO 2005 data for chronic viral hepatitis (primarily HBV and HCV new chronic infections). Confidence limited due to heterogeneous causes and diagnostic challenges.
source: WHO Hepatitis B and C Surveillance Report 2005

reasoning: Acute kidney injury in advanced liver disease. Incidence ~3-4 per 100k per year, occurring in ~10-15% of cirrhosis patients.
source: Ginès P et al. (2003). Hepatorenal syndrome. Lancet. 362(9398):1819-1827

reasoning: Diaphragmatic hernia is a congenital anomaly with incidence of approximately 1 in 2,500 to 1 in 4,500 live births (2-4 per 100k births, approximately 3.2 per 100k applied to general population). More common on left side. Prenatal diagnosis rate increased from ~50% in 1990s to ~80% by 2005 due to improved ultrasound screening.
source: Birth Defects Registry data and epidemiological surveys (2000-2005)

reasoning: Epidemiological data for Heroin Dependence requires further investigation.

HSV is extremely common globally. Prevalence: HSV-1 ~67% of adults <50 years (WHO 2012 estimate for global burden), HSV-2 ~11% globally = combined ~67,000 per 100k prevalence. Incidence of new infections: estimated 1-2% of susceptible population annually, roughly 1,500 per 100k person-years for primary infections (combining HSV-1 and HSV-2). This is somewhat of an umbrella term (HSV-1 vs HSV-2 have different epidemiology), reducing confidence. Data quality strong for prevalence, moderate for incidence.
source: Looker KJ et al. (2015). Global estimates of prevalent and incident herpes simplex virus type 2 infections in 2012. PLoS One. 10(1):e114989

reasoning: VHL syndrome is an autosomal dominant familial cancer syndrome with birth prevalence of approximately 1 in 36,000 to 1 in 45,000 (2.2-2.8 per 100k). Incidence not well-defined for genetic syndromes; prevalence is more appropriate. Characterized by hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytomas.
source: GeneReviews: Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome (NCBI Bookshelf); Maher ER et al. (2011) von Hippel-Lindau disease. Lancet. 379(9819):1050-1061

reasoning: Congenital aganglionic megacolon with well-documented incidence of approximately 1 in 5,000 live births (20 per 100k births), translating to roughly 2.5 per 100k general population per year.
source: Amiel J et al. (2008). Hirschsprung disease, associated syndromes and genetics: a review. J Med Genet. 45(1):1-14

reasoning: Reporting incidence of new diagnoses. LCH overall incidence is 4-9 cases per million population per year, approximately 0.5 per 100k, predominantly affecting children with peak incidence ages 1-4 years.
source: Guyot-Goubin A et al. (2008). Descriptive epidemiology of childhood Langerhans cell histiocytosis in France, 2000-2004. Pediatr Blood Cancer. 51(1):71-75

reasoning: New HIV infections globally in 2005: ~2.7 million cases (UNAIDS). With global population ~6.4 billion, incidence ~42 per 100k person-years. High-quality surveillance data from UNAIDS/WHO.
source: UNAIDS/WHO AIDS Epidemic Update 2005

reasoning: Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) is a well-defined malignancy with strong epidemiological data from cancer registries. Global incidence approximately 2.5-3.5 per 100k, with variation by geography and age. Bimodal age distribution with peaks in 20s-30s and 50s+. Using global average estimate of 3.0 per 100k from GLOBOCAN-type data. Strong cancer registry coverage worldwide provides reliable estimates.
source: Cancer registry epidemiological estimates; global Hodgkin lymphoma incidence from international cancer surveillance data circa 2000-2010

reasoning: Limited epidemiological data available for Homocystinuria.
Limited epidemiological data available for Hookworm Infections.
Reporting incidence of new diagnoses. Huntington disease has global incidence ~0.5-1 per 100k person-years based on neurological registry data and population studies.
source: Pringsheim T et al. (2012). The incidence and prevalence of Huntington's disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Mov Disord. 27(9):1083-91

reasoning: Molar pregnancy incidence varies geographically: 0.6-1.1 per 1000 pregnancies in Western countries, 2-3 per 1000 in parts of Asia. Estimated global average ~2.5 per 100k total population (accounting for reproductive age women and birth rates).
source: Berkowitz RS, Goldstein DP. (2009). Clinical practice: Molar pregnancy. N Engl J Med. 360:1639-1645

reasoning: Hypercholesterolemia is a chronic metabolic condition measured as prevalence. WHO data shows ~15% of global adults have elevated total cholesterol (>5.0 mmol/L or 193 mg/dL) = 15,000 per 100k. Using prevalence as incidence is poorly defined for this chronic condition.
source: WHO Global Health Observatory data on raised cholesterol

reasoning: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder affecting LDL metabolism. Global prevalence estimated at 1 per 300-500 individuals (~200-330 per 100k). Using consensus global prevalence estimate of ~250 per 100k. Chronic genetic condition, therefore prevalence metric is appropriate. Includes both heterozygous (most common) and homozygous forms.
source: Castillo-Martínez A et al. (2005). Familial hypercholesterolemia: Epidemiology and genetics. Rev Invest Clin. 57(3):401-408

reasoning: Hyperglycemia is primarily a laboratory finding and symptom rather than a disease diagnosis. Estimated incidence based on new-onset diabetes mellitus and impaired fasting glucose progression to clinical hyperglycemia. Low confidence due to hyperglycemia being a symptom of underlying conditions (diabetes, stress hyperglycemia, medication-induced) rather than an independent disease entity. Estimate of 18 per 100k based on type 2 diabetes incidence.
Congenital and acquired forms. Incidence ~2-5 per 100k per year including neonatal hypoglycemia and insulinomas. Lower confidence due to heterogeneity.
Chronic condition measured as prevalence. Global prevalence approximately 35% of adults (35,000 per 100k) with elevated cholesterol levels based on WHO criteria.
source: WHO Global Health Observatory data on raised cholesterol

reasoning: Hyperopia (farsightedness) prevalence ~10% population. Incidence ~100 per 100k (new diagnoses).

reasoning: Hypertension (blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg) is measured as prevalence, not incidence, as it is a chronic condition. Global prevalence ~25% of adults (~25,000 per 100k) based on WHO and national health surveys. High confidence from multiple large epidemiological studies.

reasoning: Hyperthyroidism measured as prevalence (~1.2% of population, 1,200 per 100k) rather than incidence, as it represents the burden of existing thyroid hormone excess. reasoning: Hypoglycemia is a biochemical finding/symptom rather than a specific disease entity. Occurs across multiple etiologies (diabetes medication, insulinoma, liver disease, hormonal deficiencies). No meaningful population-based incidence data for hypoglycemia as a general category.

reasoning: Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors (neuroendocrine tumors of GI tract) have variable incidence by anatomic site. reasoning: EDS autosomal dominant types are rare genetic disorders. Overall EDS prevalence estimated ~1 in 5,000 (200 per 100k), with autosomal dominant forms comprising majority. Limited epidemiological data; estimates based on case reports and clinical registries.
Lethal skeletal dysplasia caused by COL2A1 mutations. Extremely rare at <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Most cases are stillborn or die in neonatal period.
22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge/velocardiofacial syndrome). Birth incidence ~1 per 4000-6000 (20 per 100k births) based on genetic studies.

reasoning: Rare skeletal dysplasia, <0.1 per 100k births.

Pituitary cachexia: very rare manifestation of advanced pituitary disease. Likely <0.1 per 100k.

source: Lindholm J et al. (2001). Incidence of Cushing disease. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 86(1):117-123

reasoning: Primarily colorectal cancer. GLOBOCAN 2005 data shows colorectal cancer incidence ~19-20 per 100k globally.

reasoning: Pathological process descriptor, not a disease entity. Too broad to estimate meaningfully.

Generic descriptor, not a disease entity. Too broad to map meaningfully.

Rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder accounting for 5-30% of craniosynostosis cases. Craniosynostosis occurs in ~1 per 2,000-3,000 births. SCS estimated at ~0.08 per 100k person-years based on birth prevalence studies. Low confidence due to limited population-based epidemiological data.

Ganglioneuroblastoma is a rare neural crest tumor, subtype of neuroblastoma. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k children based on pediatric oncology registry data. Limited epidemiological literature; confidence constrained by rarity and lack of comprehensive population-based surveillance.

Rare dermal and subcutaneous sarcoma with incidence approximately 0.8-1 per million globally (0.008-0.01 per 100k person-years). Well-defined entity but limited epidemiological registry data; confidence capped at 0.55 due to lack of verifiable primary source with exact URL.

reasoning: Giant cell fibroblastoma is a rare benign/locally aggressive fibrous tumor primarily affecting children and young adults. Waardenburg Syndrome Type 2 is a rare autosomal dominant disorder with estimated incidence <0.1-0.5 per 100k births. Limited systematic epidemiological data; primarily documented through case reports and genetic studies.

Piebaldism is a rare autosomal dominant genodermatosis. Prevalence estimated at ~1.5 per 100k based on limited case reports and small case series. Well-defined genetic condition but sparse epidemiological data limits confidence.

Rhabdoid tumors are rare malignant kidney neoplasms primarily affecting children under age 5. Estimated to represent 1-2% of pediatric renal tumors (~0.07-0.2 per 100k population). reasoning: Primary lung sarcomas are rare, comprising <1% of lung malignancies. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on cancer registry data. Specific subtype of soft tissue sarcoma with lung origin.

Umbrella term covering multiple types of hand deformities (congenital anomalies like polydactyly/syndactyly and acquired deformities from arthritis/trauma) with vastly different epidemiological characteristics and clinical significance. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully.

Claw hand is a clinical deformity/manifestation of multiple underlying conditions (ulnar nerve palsy, leprosy, hand trauma, systemic conditions) rather than a primary disease entity. Cannot estimate incidence independently without specifying the underlying etiology.

Microphthalmos is a rare congenital eye condition characterized by abnormally small eyes. Incidence estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on ophthalmologic literature and case reports. Actual incidence varies by population and genetic factors.

Hypertrophic skin conditions (keloids, hypertrophic scars, acanthosis nigricans) are relatively common, estimated at ~5 per 1000 population (500 per 100k prevalence). Secondary peritoneal malignancies represent metastatic spread from various primary cancers (gastric, ovarian, pancreatic, colorectal). reasoning: Type I Cockayne syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Incidence estimated at <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency; no systematic epidemiological registry available.

Mastitis-metritis-agalactia (MMA) syndrome is primarily a veterinary condition affecting lactating animals (especially swine) post-partum, not a human disease. Severe chronic neutropenia (SCN) is a rare condition with incidence ~0.15 per 100k (1-2 per million) and prevalence ~2.5 per 100k. Reporting both metrics as it has established incidence and prevalence data. Confidence moderate due to relative rarity and limited large-scale epidemiological studies.

reasoning: Erythroleukemia is a rare subtype of AML, comprising ~5-10% of acute leukemias globally. Estimated incidence ~0.25 per 100k based on AML incidence (3-4 per 100k) and proportion of erythroid differentiation subtypes. Limited published epidemiological data specific to this subtype.

TIA incidence estimated at ~150 per 100k person-years based on stroke registry data. Acute neurological condition with clear diagnostic onset, making incidence the appropriate metric. Geographic variation reflects differences in stroke surveillance and population age structure.

reasoning: Trichiasis is a specific eyelid condition with limited epidemiological data. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence due to chronic/intermittent nature. reasoning: Amyloid plaques are pathological findings (misfolded protein deposits) rather than a diagnosable disease entity. reasoning: Ocular hypertension is a chronic condition defined by elevated intraocular pressure (>21 mmHg) without optic nerve damage, affecting approximately 4.2% of adults globally. reasoning: Allergic conjunctivitis measured as prevalence (chronic, recurrent condition). Global prevalence estimated at ~10% of population (10,000 per 100k) based on epidemiological studies of allergic diseases. Affects individuals seasonally and year-round depending on allergen exposure.

reasoning: VKC is a chronic allergic inflammation affecting primarily children/adolescents in warm climates. Estimated prevalence ~0.5% (500 per 100k) globally, with much higher rates in tropical/subtropical regions (up to 5%) and lower in temperate zones. Geographic variation is high.

reasoning: Rare cardiac pre-excitation syndrome with short PR interval and normal QRS. Estimated <1 per 100k based on case series. Low confidence due to diagnostic controversy and limited population-based studies.

reasoning: GBS pneumonia primarily affects neonates and immunocompromised adults. Estimated ~2 per 100k globally combining neonatal and adult cases. Data quality moderate as GBS not always identified in pneumonia surveillance.

This is not a disease entity but rather a descriptor for the diagnostic process in psychiatry. Unmappable to disease incidence data.

reasoning: Umbrella term for severe epilepsy syndromes with developmental regression. Aggregate estimate summing major subtypes: Lennox-Gastaut (~0.26), West syndrome (~0.3), Dravet (~0.04), Ohtahara (~0.03), and other DEE (~0.6). Total ~1.2 per 100k. Moderate heterogeneity.

Unmappable - 'Recurrent Carcinoma' is a disease state descriptor (recurrence of any cancer type), not a distinct disease entity with its own incidence rate. Recurrence rates vary dramatically by cancer type, stage, and treatment.
Congenital hypofibrinogenemia is rare, ~0.1-0.2 per 100k. Acquired forms (from liver disease, DIC) are more common but typically secondary conditions. Estimating congenital form only.
Severe major depressive episodes estimated at ~65 per 100k person-years based on WHO mental health surveys. Severe depression represents approximately 30-40% of all MDD episodes.
source: WHO World Mental Health Survey Initiative (2004)

reasoning: Rare hereditary kidney disorder affecting water reabsorption. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on genetic disorder registries.
source: Bichet DG. (2006). Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Adv Chronic Kidney Dis. 13(2):96-104

reasoning: Axillary lymph node metastases occur primarily from breast cancer (most common), melanoma, and lung cancer. Estimated ~8.5 per 100k based on breast cancer metastasis patterns, but no dedicated registry data for this specific site.
Congenital absence of one eye (anophthalmia/microphthalmia spectrum) is extremely rare, estimated <0.3 per 100k births based on birth defect registries.
Unmappable: psychoticism is a personality trait dimension (Eysenck's model), not a disease entity with onset. Cannot assign meaningful incidence or prevalence to a personality characteristic.
Rare autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia (COL2A1 mutations). Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis occurs in ~2-3 per 1000 live births (~200-300 per 100k births), with male predominance. Based on population-based birth defect registries and pediatric surgical databases.
source: MacMahon B (2006). The continuing enigma of pyloric stenosis of infancy. Epidemiology. 17(2):195-201

reasoning: Radiologic/pathologic finding rather than disease entity. Aggregate BOTEC summing major causes: alcoholic cerebellar degeneration (~7), spinocerebellar ataxias (~3), multiple system atrophy (~2), paraneoplastic (~1), other causes (~2) = ~15 per 100k. Heterogeneous etiologies with poor unified tracking.

Childhood apraxia of speech prevalence ~0.1-0.2% of children (100-200 per 100k children, using midpoint 150). Prevalence is the standard metric for this developmental disorder. Incidence less meaningful for congenital/early childhood onset conditions.
source: Shriberg LD et al. (1997). Prevalence of speech delay in 6-year-old children and comorbidity with language impairment. J Speech Lang Hear Res. 40(6):1245-60

cui_name: Hereditary Motor and Sensory Neuropathy Type I
reasoning: HMSN Type I is synonymous with CMT1. Using prevalence for genetic condition. CMT1 accounts for ~60% of CMT cases, prevalence ~12 per 100k globally based on neuromuscular epidemiology studies.
source: Martyn CN & Hughes RA. (1997). Epidemiology of peripheral neuropathy. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 62(4):310-318

reasoning: Umbrella term covering diverse etiologies (noise-induced, age-related presbycusis, infection, ototoxic drugs, trauma) with vastly different incidence rates and age distributions. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully without specification.
Umbrella term for head and neck cancers. GLOBOCAN 2005 data shows combined head/neck cancer incidence ~13.5 per 100k globally, including oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx cancers.
source: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108

reasoning: Central auditory processing disorder prevalence estimated at 2-3% of school-aged children (~2500 per 100k children), translating to ~0.8% of general population (800 per 100k). Chronic neurodevelopmental condition, so prevalence is appropriate metric.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for embryonal tumors including neuroblastoma (~0.2), Wilms tumor (~0.14), hepatoblastoma (~0.03), medulloblastoma (~0.1), retinoblastoma (~0.06) = ~0.5 per 100k overall population. These are primarily pediatric cancers. Low confidence due to heterogeneity.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for embryonal and mixed malignant tumors. Similar to embryonal cancers, includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, medulloblastoma. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k. Low confidence due to umbrella categorization.
Malignant nasal cavity cancer incidence ~0.5-0.8 per 100k based on SEER and international cancer registry data. Rare cancer with moderate data quality.
Extremely rare autosomal dominant form of juvenile Parkinsonism. Estimated <0.02 per 100k based on genetic case series. Very limited epidemiological data, mostly case reports.

Early-onset autosomal recessive parkinsonism (including PARK2, PARK6, PARK7) accounts for ~5-10% of early-onset PD cases (<50 years). With early-onset PD at ~8-16 per 100k, AR forms ~0.8 per 100k. Limited population-based data.
source: Klein C, Schlossmacher MG. (2006). The genetics of Parkinson disease: Implications for neurological care. Nat Clin Pract Neurol. 2(3):136-146

reasoning: Experimental parkinsonism refers to laboratory-induced models in research animals (MPTP models, 6-OHDA lesions), not a naturally occurring human clinical condition. Not applicable for epidemiological mapping.
Extremely rare genetic form of juvenile Parkinsonism with family history. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on genetic epidemiology. No robust population-based incidence studies.
Juvenile-onset Parkinsonism (onset <21 years) is rare, estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on epidemiological surveys. Includes both genetic and sporadic cases. Limited population-based data.
source: Van Den Eeden SK et al. (2003). Incidence of Parkinson's disease: variation by age, gender, and race/ethnicity. Am J Epidemiol. 157(11):1015-22

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC summing major inherited metabolic disorders affecting brain: mitochondrial disorders (~2), lysosomal storage diseases (~3), aminoacidopathies (~4), organic acidemias (~3), urea cycle defects (~1), peroxisomal disorders (~1), other (~1) = ~15 per 100k births. Heterogeneous group with overlap.

Aggregate BOTEC for inborn metabolic brain diseases. Essentially synonymous with C0752107 and C0752110. Sum of major inherited metabolic disorders affecting brain development/function = ~15 per 100k births. Heterogeneous umbrella term.

cui_name: Central Nervous System Inborn Metabolic Diseases
reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC for CNS inborn errors of metabolism. Largely overlaps with C0752107. Includes mitochondrial disorders, aminoacidopathies, lysosomal storage diseases, organic acidemias affecting CNS = ~15 per 100k births. Low confidence due to heterogeneity.

Umbrella term for congenital myopathies (centronuclear, nemaline, central core, etc.). Combined birth incidence ~1-2 per 100k births. Moderate confidence due to diagnostic heterogeneity and reporting variability.
source: Colombo I et al. (2015). Congenital myopathies: clinical features and frequency of individual subtypes. Neuromuscul Disord. 25(4):341-345

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major perinatal brain injuries: hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (150 per 100k births), intraventricular hemorrhage (30), periventricular leukomalacia (20). Highly heterogeneous umbrella term with significant overlap.

Reading disabilities is an umbrella term including dyslexia and other reading disorders. Prevalence estimated at 10-20% of school-age population (15,000 per 100k represents 15%). Broader category than dyslexia alone. Prevalence is appropriate metric for developmental/learning disorders.
Most common gastric polyp type. Found in 1-2% of endoscopies, translating to ~50 per 100k population incidence based on endoscopy rates. Limited population-based data.
Becker muscular dystrophy incidence ~3 per 100k male births based on population studies. X-linked recessive dystrophinopathy, milder than Duchenne.
source: Emery AE (2002). The muscular dystrophies. Lancet. 359(9307):687-695

reasoning: Congenital vascular malformation with detection rate ~1-1.5 per million per year (0.1-0.15 per 100k). Using incidence of clinical detection/diagnosis.
source: Stapf C et al. (2006). Epidemiology and natural history of arteriovenous malformations. Neurosurg Focus. 11(5):e1

reasoning: Drug-induced lupus (lupus-like syndrome) estimated at ~2 per 100k based on medication exposure rates and incidence studies. Lower confidence due to variable diagnostic criteria and underreporting.

Primarily H. pylori gastritis. Reporting incidence of new symptomatic gastritis cases ~450 per 100k. Prevalence much higher (~50% globally) but most asymptomatic. Incidence varies by region and declining in developed countries. Confidence limited by diagnostic heterogeneity.

Neurological manifestation occurring in 10-15% of Lyme disease cases. In endemic areas (Europe, North America) Lyme incidence ~10-20 per 100k, giving neuroborreliosis ~1-3 per 100k. Global average lower due to geographic restriction; estimate ~1.2 per 100k.
source: Halperin JJ et al. (2007). Practice parameter: treatment of nervous system Lyme disease. Neurology. 69(1):91-102

reasoning: Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major tauopathies: Alzheimer's disease (~12-15), progressive supranuclear palsy (~1), corticobasal degeneration (~0.5), Pick's disease (~0.5), frontotemporal dementia with tau (~1). Total ~18 per 100k. Heterogeneous umbrella term with variable clinical presentation.

Sclerocystic ovaries is an older term related to PCOS. Reporting prevalence (~6% of women of reproductive age) rather than incidence, as this is a chronic morphological finding. Confidence limited by unclear modern diagnostic criteria and overlap with PCOS.

Renal anemia is a chronic complication of CKD. Prevalence metric used (~800 per 100k based on CKD stage 3-5 prevalence of ~10% with ~80% developing anemia). Moderate confidence due to being a complication rather than primary disease.
X-linked form represents ~60% of dyskeratosis congenita cases. Total DC incidence <0.1 per 100k births, so X-linked form ~0.06 per 100k births. Extremely rare inherited bone marrow failure syndrome.
source: Dokal I. (2011). Dyskeratosis congenita. Hematology Am Soc Hematol Educ Program. 2011:480-486

reasoning: Rare HPV-induced disease. Combined juvenile-onset (0.1-0.4 per 100k children) and adult-onset (0.05-0.1 per 100k adults) yields global estimate ~0.15 per 100k.
source: Derkay CS et al. (2008). Task force on recurrent respiratory papillomas: a preliminary report. Arch Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 121(12):1386-91

reasoning: Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas (paragangliomas) comprise ~10-15% of all pheochromocytoma cases. Total pheochromocytoma incidence ~0.8 per 100k, yielding ~0.1 per 100k for extra-adrenal.
source: Beard CM et al. (1983). Occurrence of pheochromocytoma in Rochester, Minnesota. Mayo Clin Proc. 58(12):802-4

reasoning: Generic morphological descriptor, not a specific disease entity. Too broad and non-specific to map to any incidence rate.
Merosin-deficient congenital muscular dystrophy (MDC1A) estimated at ~0.3 per 100k births based on registry data. Represents about 30-40% of all CMD cases.
source: Mostacciuolo ML et al. (1996). Genetic epidemiology of congenital muscular dystrophy in Italy. Am J Med Genet. 63(1):113-117

reasoning: Rare aggressive variant of RCC representing ~1-5% of all RCC cases. Global RCC incidence ~4-5 per 100k, sarcomatoid variant ~3% = 0.15 per 100k.
source: de Peralta-Venturina M et al. (2001). Sarcomatoid differentiation in renal cell carcinoma. Am J Surg Pathol. 25(3):275-84

reasoning: Rare benign epilepsy-associated brain tumor, primarily in children/young adults. Estimated ~0.05 per 100k based on it representing <1-2% of brain tumors in surgical epilepsy series.

Therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) occurs after chemotherapy/radiation, representing ~10-15% of all MDS cases. With total MDS incidence ~4-5 per 100k, t-MDS estimated at ~0.5 per 100k. Based on cancer registry data and literature reviews.
source: Smith SM et al. (2003). Clinical-cytogenetic associations in 306 patients with therapy-related myelodysplasia and myeloid leukemia. Blood. 102(1):43-52

reasoning: Systemic calcium oxalate deposition, primarily from primary hyperoxaluria. Extremely rare genetic metabolic disorder with estimated incidence 0.03-0.1 per 100k (median ~0.05). Based on case series and registry data.
Overly broad descriptor term for any neurological disease state or complication, not a specific diagnosable condition. Too generic and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully.

Extremely rare variant of bullous pemphigoid with prurigo nodularis-like lesions. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency. Even bullous pemphigoid itself is only ~2-4 per 100k in elderly.

Chronic hereditary condition reported as prevalence, not incidence. Includes Alport syndrome (~3 per 100k) and thin basement membrane disease (~50 per 100k). Using prevalence estimate of ~50 per 100k for hereditary causes of hematuria.

Secondary polycythemia is a chronic condition measured by prevalence. Estimated ~1.5% prevalence (1,500 per 100k) based on population studies, though varies by altitude and underlying conditions. Limited systematic epidemiological data.
Extremely rare congenital condition, often associated with DiGeorge syndrome. Isolated congenital absence estimated at <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency.
ALPS is an extremely rare genetic immunodeficiency syndrome affecting lymphocyte apoptosis. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on case registry data. Fewer than 500 cases reported worldwide.

cui_name: Adult Clear Cell Sarcoma of Soft Parts
reasoning: Clear cell sarcoma represents approximately 1% of adult soft tissue sarcomas. With adult soft tissue sarcoma incidence of ~4 per 100k, clear cell sarcoma incidence is ~0.04 per 100k adults.
source: SEER Cancer Statistics Review, adult soft tissue sarcoma histology distribution

cui_name: Childhood Clear Cell Sarcoma of Soft Parts
reasoning: Clear cell sarcoma accounts for approximately 1% of childhood soft tissue sarcomas. With childhood soft tissue sarcoma incidence of ~1.0 per 100k, clear cell sarcoma incidence is ~0.01 per 100k children.
source: SEER Cancer Statistics Review, pediatric soft tissue sarcoma data

reasoning: Rare pediatric brain tumor representing ~1-4% of pediatric CNS tumors. Estimated ~0.15 per 100k overall (higher in pediatric population ~0.3-0.4 per 100k children) based on CBTRUS pediatric tumor data.
source: CBTRUS Statistical Report on Primary Brain Tumors in Children

reasoning: Paget disease of bone is chronic, measured by prevalence. Global age-adjusted prevalence ~1% (1,000 per 100k), though highly variable: 2-3% in UK, <1% in Asia. Using global average estimate.
source: Ralston SH et al. (2008). Paget's disease of bone. Lancet. 372(9633):155-163

reasoning: Hypopharyngeal cancer incidence ~0.8 per 100k globally based on GLOBOCAN 2005 data. Accounts for ~5% of head and neck cancers. Higher rates in Southern Europe and parts of Asia.
source: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)

reasoning: Grass pollen allergy is chronic and measured by prevalence. Global prevalence estimated ~12% (12,000 per 100k) based on allergic rhinitis epidemiology, with grass as major allergen.
source: Bousquet J et al. (2008). Allergic Rhinitis and its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) guidelines. Allergy. 63(S86):8-160

reasoning: Cystic fibrosis (CF) incidence ~1 per 3,500 births in Caucasians, much rarer in other populations. Global average approximately 0.8 per 100k births. Using birth-based incidence as CF is congenital.
source: Farrell PM. (2008). The prevalence of cystic fibrosis in the European Union. J Cyst Fibros. 7(5):450-453

reasoning: Accounts for ~20-30% of ischemic strokes. Global ischemic stroke incidence ~120-150 per 100k, cardioembolic portion ~25-30% = 40 per 100k.
source: Feigin VL et al. (2003). Stroke epidemiology: a review of population-based studies of incidence, prevalence, and case-fatality. Lancet Neurol. 2(1):43-53

reasoning: Birth incidence ~1 in 4,000 live births (2.4 per 100k children). Prevalence ~24 per 100k. Based on population studies but limited systematic surveillance.
Umbrella term covering congenital (CAH ~5-6 per 100k births) and acquired adrenal hyperplasia. Dominated by congenital cases. Heterogeneous entity with variable etiologies.

Pathophysiological state (reduced cerebral blood flow) rather than disease entity. Results from multiple conditions (stroke, cardiac disease, hypotension) and not tracked independently in disease registries.

Reporting incidence of new diagnoses. Uterine carcinosarcomas represent ~3-5% of uterine malignancies. With endometrial cancer at ~15 per 100k women globally, carcinosarcomas estimated at 0.5 per 100k overall population (1.0 per 100k women).
source: SEER Cancer Statistics Review, based on relative frequency of uterine carcinosarcoma among uterine cancers

reasoning: Keratocystic odontogenic tumor (formerly odontogenic keratocyst) estimated at ~0.5 per 100k based on oral pathology registry data. Accounts for 10-15% of jaw cysts.

Soft drusen are clinical findings (retinal deposits) associated with early/intermediate AMD, not a disease per se. Reporting prevalence as incidence poorly defined for gradual accumulation process. Adults >55 years show soft drusen prevalence ~15-25% in developed countries (using conservative 15% of ~30% global population >55 = ~4,500 per 100k overall).
source: Klein R et al. (2004). Prevalence of age-related maculopathy. Ophthalmology. 111(6):1288-97

reasoning: This is a pathological finding/descriptor rather than a primary disease entity. It occurs secondary to conditions like hypertension, aortic stenosis, or coarctation. Not independently mappable to incidence data.
This is not a disease entity but a chromosomal/genetic region (chromosome 1q21) containing genes for epidermal proteins. Cannot map genetic loci to disease incidence.

Familial medullary thyroid carcinoma (FMTC) is a hereditary form of MTC, accounting for ~25% of MTC cases. Total MTC incidence ~0.2 per 100k, so FMTC estimated at ~0.02 per 100k. Based on thyroid cancer registry data.
source: Roman S et al. (2006). Medullary thyroid cancer: a review. JAMA Surg. 141(9):815-820

reasoning: Rare hereditary brachial plexus neuropathy. Overall neuralgic amyotrophy incidence ~2-3 per 100k, with hereditary forms representing <20% of cases. Estimated <0.5 per 100k for hereditary variant.
source: van Alfen N. (2011). Clinical and pathophysiological concepts of neuralgic amyotrophy. Nat Rev Neurol. 7(6):315-322

reasoning: Autosomal dominant centronuclear myopathy (DNM2-related) is extremely rare, <0.05 per 100k births. Fewer than 200 families reported worldwide. Specific genetic subtype of centronuclear myopathy.

Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) occurs in ~10% of newborns with Down syndrome. Global Down syndrome birth incidence ~1.4 per 1000 births, so TAM incidence ~1.5 per 100k births. Limited population-based registry data available.
source: Gamis AS et al. (2003). Natural history of transient myeloproliferative disorder clinically diagnosed in Down syndrome neonates: COG study. Blood. 102(24):4205-4206

reasoning: Complex I deficiency is the most common mitochondrial respiratory chain disorder, estimated at ~1-2 per 100k births based on newborn screening and clinical studies. Causes Leigh syndrome, MELAS, and other presentations.
source: Schaefer AM et al. (2008). Prevalence of mitochondrial DNA disease in adults. Ann Neurol. 63:35-39

reasoning: Rare neurodegenerative disorder affecting FMR1 premutation carriers, primarily older males. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on premutation carrier frequency and penetrance data.
source: Jacquemont S et al. (2004). Penetrance of the fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome in a premutation carrier population. JAMA. 291(4):460-469

reasoning: Rare X-linked genetic syndrome caused by PHF8 gene mutations. Very few families reported worldwide. Estimated <0.05 per 100k births.
Specific genetic subtype of cone-rod dystrophy associated with SEMA4A gene mutations. Extremely rare, <0.1 per 100k births based on genetic registry data.

Prevalence-based metric appropriate for this chronic male infertility condition. Nonobstructive azoospermia accounts for ~60% of azoospermia cases, which affects ~1% of all men, yielding ~600 per 100k males.
source: Wosnitzer M et al. (2014). Review of the genetic basis of male infertility. J Assist Reprod Genet. 31(8):925-946

reasoning: Autosomal dominant form represents ~5-10% of dyskeratosis congenita cases. Even rarer than X-linked form, <0.01 per 100k births based on genetic registry data and case series.
source: Dokal I. (2011). Dyskeratosis congenita. Hematology Am Soc Hematol Educ Program. 2011:480-486

reasoning: Umbrella term for mitochondrial disorders affecting brain including MELAS, MERRF, Leigh syndrome, etc. Aggregate estimate ~1.5 per 100k births based on combined mitochondrial disease incidence. Confidence limited by heterogeneity and diagnostic challenges.
source: Schaefer AM et al. (2008). Prevalence of mitochondrial DNA disease in adults. Ann Neurol. 63(1):35-39

reasoning: Extremely rare genetic skeletal dysplasia with cranial sclerosis and metaphyseal widening. <100 reported cases worldwide. Birth prevalence <0.01 per 100,000 based on case literature. Autosomal dominant form rarer than recessive.

Clinical manifestation rather than specific disease entity. 'Recurrent skin infections' encompasses diverse etiologies (bacterial, fungal, viral) and underlying causes (immunodeficiency, diabetes, barrier dysfunction). No unified epidemiological tracking.

RP35 is a specific genetic subtype of retinitis pigmentosa caused by RPGR mutations. While overall RP prevalence is ~25 per 100k, RP35 accounts for small fraction of cases. Estimated <0.5 per 100k, classified as extremely rare.
Specific genetic subtype of ectrodactyly caused by TP63 mutations. Extremely rare congenital limb malformation with <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports and genetic databases.

Intrahepatic form of biliary atresia. Total biliary atresia incidence ~1 per 100k births globally, with intrahepatic form comprising ~10-20% of cases. Estimated at ~0.5 per 100k births based on pediatric hepatology literature.
source: Hartley JL et al. (2009). Biliary atresia. Lancet. 374(9702):1704-1713

cui_name: Indifference to Pain, Congenital, Autosomal Recessive
reasoning: Congenital insensitivity to pain (CIPA/HSAN type IV) is extremely rare, estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports from multiple countries.
Not a disease but a genetic trait - the ability to digest lactose in adulthood. Present in ~35% of global adults (90% Northern Europeans, ~10% East Asians). Unmappable as a disease concept.
This is a cytogenetic abnormality/chromosomal phenomenon, not a clinical disease entity. It's a laboratory finding that may occur in various contexts but is not tracked as a disease diagnosis.
Rare autosomal recessive inherited retinal dystrophy, estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. More common in East Asian populations. No systematic epidemiological studies available.
Rare lethal skeletal dysplasia caused by SOX9 mutations. Birth prevalence estimated at 0.05-1.6 per 100,000 births based on case registries. High neonatal mortality.
source: Unger S et al. (2012). Campomelic dysplasia. In: GeneReviews. University of Washington, Seattle

reasoning: BPES Type I defined by presence of ovarian failure/premature ovarian insufficiency in females. Birth incidence estimated <0.1 per 100k based on BPES overall rarity and Type I representing subset of cases.
source: de Baere E et al. (2001). Spectrum of FOXL2 gene mutations in blepharophimosis-ptosis-epicanthus inversus (BPES) families demonstrates a genotype-phenotype correlation. Hum Mol Genet. 10(15):1591-600

reasoning: Sporadic ALS accounts for ~90-95% of all ALS cases. Total ALS incidence ~2 per 100k, sporadic form ~1.8 per 100k based on population registries.
source: Logroscino G et al. (2010). Incidence of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis in Europe. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 81(4):385-390

reasoning: Lethal acantholytic EB is an extremely rare, severe variant. <50 cases reported in literature, incidence <0.01 per 100k births. Neonatal lethal condition.
Autosomal recessive metabolic disorder, fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency.
Extremely rare skeletal dysplasia with very few documented cases. Originally described in Missouri kindred. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.
Extremely rare genetic subtype (PARK2/Parkin mutations) causing juvenile-onset Parkinsonism. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on genetic prevalence studies, but no systematic incidence data available.
BPES overall is rare (~1 in 50,000). Autosomal recessive Type I is extremely rare subtype. Most BPES is autosomal dominant. Estimated <0.05 per 100k based on case literature.

cui_name: Progressive Familial Heart Block, Type Ib
reasoning: Rare autosomal dominant cardiac conduction disorder, Type Ib variant (PFHBI). Fewer than 100 families described in literature. Progressive familial heart block overall is extremely rare.

Not a disease entity but a normal anatomical/physiological state describing endometrial tissue after menopause. No associated pathology unless modified by terms like atrophy, hyperplasia, or carcinoma.

CIS represents first clinical episode of CNS demyelination. Estimated global incidence ~4 per 100k based on MS registry data showing CIS incidence roughly 40-50% of MS incidence. Geographic variation parallels MS epidemiology.
source: Miller DH et al. (2005). Clinically isolated syndromes suggestive of multiple sclerosis, part I: natural history, pathogenesis, diagnosis, and prognosis. Lancet Neurol. 4(5):281-288

reasoning: Reporting prevalence for chronic coagulation disorder. Acquired thrombophilia is an umbrella term including antiphospholipid syndrome (most common, ~50 per 100k), malignancy-associated, and other causes. Estimated aggregate prevalence ~80 per 100k. Confidence limited by heterogeneity and lack of unified registry data.
Specific genetic subtype (type 2, GPD1L gene) of Brugada syndrome. Represents small fraction of all Brugada cases. Estimated ~0.2 per 100k based on proportion of genetic subtypes.

LCA13 is a specific genetic subtype caused by RDH12 mutations. LCA overall incidence is 2-3 per 100,000 births. LCA13 accounts for ~4-5% of all LCA cases, making it <0.15 per 100k births. Extremely rare specific subtype.
source: Koenekoop RK. (2004). An overview of Leber congenital amaurosis: a model to understand human retinal development. Surv Ophthalmol. 49(4):379-398

reasoning: Extremely rare X-linked dominant neuromuscular disorder with <50 documented families worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data available.
Obsolete term for familial combined hyperlipidemia. Measured as prevalence (~1.5% of adults, 1500 per 100k) not incidence. Moderate confidence due to obsolete status and variable diagnostic criteria.
source: Genest J et al. (2003). Familial hypercholesterolemia in adults: recommendations for screening and management. CMAJ. 169(9):921-924

reasoning: Specific genetic subtype (type 8) of Brugada syndrome caused by mutations in specific gene. Overall Brugada incidence ~5 per 100k, but type 8 represents small fraction (~5-10%), estimated ~0.3 per 100k.
Specific genetic subtype (type 1) of spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy. Extremely rare monogenic form, <0.01 per 100k. Distinct from acquired cerebral palsy which is much more common.

Specific genetic subtype of spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy. Extremely rare monogenic form, <0.01 per 100k. General cerebral palsy incidence is 200-300 per 100k births, but this specific genetic subtype represents a tiny fraction.

Coronary microvascular dysfunction (cardiac syndrome X) accounts for ~10-30% of angina cases with normal coronary angiography. Estimated incidence ~15 per 100k based on diagnostic cardiac catheterization studies. Low confidence due to evolving diagnostic criteria and underrecognition in 2005.
Dysferlinopathy (LGMD2B/Miyoshi myopathy) estimated at ~0.13 per 100k based on genetic epidemiology studies. Moderate confidence due to underdiagnosis and regional variation.
source: Mahmood OA et al. (2011). Prevalence of limb-girdle muscular dystrophy. Neuromuscul Disord. 21(6):434-438

reasoning: Familial (inherited) form of CHARGE syndrome, a rare genetic disorder. Birth prevalence ~1 in 8,500-10,000 live births, translating to <0.01 per 100k person-years. Limited epidemiological data for familial subtype specifically.
source: Blake KD et al. (1998). CHARGE association: an update and review for the primary pediatrician. Clin Pediatr. 37(3):159-173

reasoning: Extremely rare sporadic bone disorder characterized by cortical hyperostosis resembling dripping candle wax. Prevalence estimated <1 per million (<0.1 per 100k). Based on case reports and small case series; no systematic epidemiological studies available.
FH-III is caused by KCNJ5 mutations. Familial hyperaldosteronism represents <1% of primary aldosteronism cases, and Type III is one of several subtypes. Extremely rare genetic disorder.
Ohtahara syndrome, extremely rare neonatal epilepsy. Estimated <0.1 per 100k live births based on case series. One of the earliest and rarest epileptic encephalopathies.
source: Yamatogi Y, Ohtahara S. (2002). Early-infantile epileptic encephalopathy with suppression-bursts, Ohtahara syndrome. Epilepsy Res. 70:S23-29

reasoning: Specific genetic subtype of cone-rod dystrophy. All cone-rod dystrophies combined affect ~1 in 40,000; type 2 represents small fraction. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births.
Extremely rare epilepsy syndrome affecting infants, also known as EIMFS. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports and epilepsy registries. Specific incidence data limited.
Rieger syndrome/anomaly is a rare genetic condition affecting anterior segment eye development. Estimated <0.1 per 100k births based on ophthalmology case series.
Pediatric idiopathic nephrotic syndrome incidence ~2-7 per 100k children per year based on pediatric nephrology registries. Using conservative estimate of 2 per 100k.

Prevalence metric appropriate for lifelong genetic condition. X-linked nonsyndromic intellectual disability affects approximately 1-2 per 1000 males (100-200 per 100k males), using conservative estimate of 150 per 100k population.
source: Lubs HA et al. (2012). X-linked intellectual disability: a vanishing diagnosis? Genet Med. 14(8):673-679

cui_name: End stage renal disease due to hypertension
reasoning: ESRD overall incidence ~35-40 per 100k, with hypertension causing ~30% of cases globally. Estimate ~11 per 100k for hypertensive ESRD based on USRDS and WHO data circa 2005.
source: US Renal Data System (USRDS) Annual Data Report 2005

reasoning: Specific genetic locus (AFIB13) for familial atrial fibrillation. Familial AF represents <5% of all AF cases, and this specific genetic subtype is exceedingly rare with limited families documented.
Familial episodic pain syndrome type 2 (FEPS2) is an extremely rare autosomal dominant disorder with episodic pain attacks. Very limited case reports in medical literature.
Specific genetic subtype of CVID (type 10). CVID overall prevalence 1-5 per 100k, but this specific subtype represents <5% of CVID cases. Extremely rare, <0.05 per 100k.
C. pneumoniae causes ~10% of community-acquired pneumonia cases. With global CAP incidence ~1500 per 100k, C. pneumoniae accounts for ~150 per 100k annually. Most infections are mild or asymptomatic.
source: Grayston JT. (2000). Background and current knowledge of Chlamydia pneumoniae and atherosclerosis. J Infect Dis. 181(Suppl 3):S402-410

Parasitic infection. Incidence ~0.3-1 per 100,000, higher in immunocompromised.

Prevalence estimated at ~0.125% (1,000 per 100k) as a subset of arthritis. Reporting as prevalence (chronic presentation). Weak epidemiological data specific to hip inflammation.

Apraxia of phonation (phonetic disintegration) affects voice quality and phoneme production in speech apraxia. Prevalence estimated at ~25 per 100k based on speech-language pathology literature. Largely acquired from stroke or neurodegenerative conditions.

Chronic heart failure reported as both incidence (~2 per 100k person-years for new diagnoses) and prevalence (~1.5% of population = 15,000 per 100k) from WHO and epidemiological studies circa 2005. Prevalence metric more clinically relevant for chronic condition. Global estimate accounting for high geographic variation.
source: WHO Global Burden of Disease Study, Framingham Heart Study data

reasoning: Chronic acquired lymphedema develops after cancer treatment (surgery/radiation) or infection. Incidence among breast cancer survivors ~10-38%, overall population incidence ~20 per 100k. Prevalence estimated 100-200 per 100k (1-2% of population) due to cancer treatment and venous insufficiency.
source: Warren AG et al. (2007). Lymphedema: a comprehensive review. Ann Plast Surg. 59(4):464-472

parent_disease: Genetic Syndromes with Organ System Involvement
reasoning: BOR syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k births based on case report frequency. No systematic population registries exist for this condition.
Congenital craniofacial anomaly (hemifacial microsomia spectrum). Incidence estimated at ~1 per 3,000-6,000 live births, approximately 0.3-0.35 per 100k births annually.
source: Congenital craniofacial anomaly epidemiology

reasoning: Townes syndrome is an extremely rare genetic disorder with anuric renal dysplasia and other congenital anomalies. Fewer than 30 cases reported in literature. Incidence estimated <0.05 per 100k births based on sparse case reports.

OPD1 is a rare X-linked genetic disorder affecting males predominantly. Prevalence estimated at <1 per 100,000 with approximately 100+ reported cases worldwide. X-linked gain-of-function mutations in FLNA gene (Xq28). Limited epidemiological data available; confidence reflects rarity and case report-based evidence rather than population registries.

reasoning: Rare X-linked dominant disorder with severe intellectual disability and skeletal dysplasia. Fewer than 1000 cases reported worldwide; estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data; incidence inferred from case report frequency.

reasoning: Umbrella term for multiple pterygium syndrome including lethal and non-lethal forms. Aggregate estimate based on combined lethal and non-lethal subtypes. Overall incidence estimated <1 per 100k births. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and limited epidemiological literature.
Developmental motor disorder. Birth incidence ~1.5-3 per 100,000 live births.
source: Colver A et al. (2014). Cerebral palsy prevalence. Pediatr Int. 56(4):449-455

reasoning: Extremely rare genodermatosis with <100 reported cases worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births. Heterogeneous group of follicular hyperkeratosis disorders.

Clinodactyly (inward curvature of 5th digit) is a congenital condition with estimated prevalence of 0.5-3% in general population, primarily isolated form. Using midpoint estimate of 1.5% = 15,000 per 100k. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence since it is a lifelong structural condition. Confidence limited by lack of systematic population-based data.
Rare skeletal birth defect affecting rib cage development. Estimated incidence 1 in 250,000-500,000 live births (~0.2-0.4 per 100k) based on birth defect registries. Mild forms likely underdiagnosed.
source: Birth Defects Registry data (NBDPS/CDC)

reasoning: Congenital absence of nails (anonychia). Rare hereditary condition with estimated incidence of 0.1-0.5 per 1 million births. Limited epidemiological data, primarily case reports and family studies.

Renal fusion disorders (primarily horseshoe kidney) occurring in 1 in 400-600 births. Incidence estimated at ~150-250 per 100k births globally. Heterogeneous category including horseshoe kidney, crossed fused ectopia, and other fusion variants with varying frequencies.
source: Robson WL et al. (2004). The changing epidemiology of renal disease in childhood. Emerg Med Clin North Am. Overview of congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT)

reasoning: Congenital hydronephrosis is the most common prenatal finding on ultrasound, detected in approximately 1-2% of pregnancies (1000-2000 per 100k births). Most cases resolve spontaneously postnatally. Point estimate of 1500 per 100k used for detected cases.
source: Nguyen HT, Herndon CD, Cooper C, et al. (2010). The Society for Fetal Urology consensus statement on the evaluation and management of antenatal hydronephrosis. J Pediatr Urol. 6(3):212-231

reasoning: Irido-corneal dysgenesis is a very rare congenital anterior segment anomaly characterized by iris hypoplasia and corneal opacification. Related to Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome spectrum. Birth incidence <0.1 per 100k. Only scattered case reports in literature.
source: Seifert AW et al. (2013). Iris hypoplasia in anterior segment dysgenesis. Ophthalmology. 120(5):1062-1068

reasoning: Congenital lamellar cataract is a specific subtype of congenital cataracts. Estimated incidence ~1-3 per 100k live births based on pediatric ophthalmology literature. Limited specific data for this subtype; confidence capped at moderate due to limited population-based registries.
source: Rahi JS et al. (2003). Congenital and infantile cataracts. Eye. 17(2):159-169

parent_disease: Congenital anomalies of the head and face
reasoning: Extremely rare congenital anomaly characterized by fusion or duplication of eye structures. <0.1 per 100k births based on case report frequency. Limited epidemiological data available.

Superficial gastritis is a histological subtype affecting mucosa only. Incidence is poorly defined as many cases are asymptomatic and identified only on biopsy. Prevalence estimated at ~1.5% globally based on H. pylori prevalence and endoscopy studies. Difficult to distinguish from other gastritis types clinically.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for gastroduodenitis (inflammation of stomach and duodenum), including acute bacterial, viral, and chemical causes. Estimated ~65 per 100k person-years. Confidence is low-moderate due to: (1) umbrella term spanning multiple etiologies (H. pylori, NSAIDs, viral, reactive), (2) difficulty distinguishing from generic gastritis in epidemiological surveys, (3) high proportion of asymptomatic or self-limited cases not captured in registries, (4) substantial geographic variation based on H. pylori prevalence.

Acute vascular emergency in colon. Incidence estimated 4-5 per 100k globally, higher in elderly populations (50+ years). Most common cause of ischemic colitis is vascular compromise from atherosclerosis or atrial fibrillation with thromboembolism. Geographic variation based on age structure and cardiovascular disease prevalence.
